greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Transpose T(n,k) of Parker's partition triangle A047812 (n >= 1 and 0 <= k <= n-1).
comment: Parker's triangle is closely associated with q-binomial coefficients and Gaussian polynomials; cf. A063746. For example, row 4 of A063746 is 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 5, 7, 7, 8, 7, 7, 5, 5, 3, 2, 1, 1, the coefficients of [8, 4], while the entries in row 4 of A047812 are the coefficients of q^(k*(4+1)) = q^(5*k) in [8, 4] where k runs from 0 to n-1 = 3. Likewise, by symmetry, "1 7 5 1" is embedded also because they are the coefficients of q^(5*(3-k)), where k runs from 0 to n-1 = 3. [Edited by _Petros Hadjicostas_, May 30 2020]
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..141, flattened
R. K. Guy, Parker's permutation problem involves the Catalan numbers, Amer. Math. Monthly 100 (1993), 287-289.
example: Row four of A047812 is 1 5 7 1, so row four of the present entry is 1 7 5 1.
Triangle T(n,k) (with rows n >= 1 and columns k = 0..n-1) begins:
maple: b:= proc(n, i, t) option remember; `if`(n=0, 1, `if`(t*i
seq(seq(T(n, k), k=0..n-1), n=1..12);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, May 30 2020
mathematica: T[n_, k_]:= SeriesCoefficient[QBinomial[2*n, n, q], {q, 0, k*(n+1)}];
Table[T[n, k], {n, 1, 12}, {k, 0, n-1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 27 2020, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: for (n=1, 10, for (k=0, n-1, print1(T(n, n-1-k), ", "); ); print(); ); \\ _Petros Hadjicostas_, May 30 2020
/* Second program, courtesy of _G. C. Greubel_ */
vector(12, n, vector(n, k, T(n,n-k))) \\ _Petros Hadjicostas_, May 31 2020
[[ T(n,n-k) for k in (1..n)] for n in (1..12)] # _G. C. Greubel_, May 31 2020
xref: Cf. A000108 (Catalan row sums), A047812, A063746.
results.author: _Alford Arnold_, Jan 26 2008
